questions.question_text: Which SQL statement accepts user input for the columns to be displayed, the table name, and WHERE condition?
questions.answer_description:
In a WHERE clause, date and characters values must be enclosed within single quotation marks.

Sample of the correct syntax -
SELECT EMPLOYEE_ID, &COLUMN_NAME

FROM EMPLOYEES -
Incorrect Answers :

A. Incorrect use of " symbol -

B. Incorrect use of ' symbol -
D. No input for table name as EMP has been use in the statement.
Refer: Introduction to Oracle9i: SQL, Oracle University Student Guide, Producing Readable Output with iSQL*PLUS, p. 7-8

discussion.content: item A is also correct, it is only dependent on him writing in case sensitive.

questions.question_text:
The CUSTOMERS table has these columns:

The CUSTOMER_ID column is the primary key for the table.
You need to determine how dispersed your customer base is.
Which expression finds the number of different countries represented in the CUSTOMERS table?

discussion.content:
SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_DATE('19-Mar-2001', 'DD-Mon-YYYY'),'fmDdspth "of" Month YYYY fmHH:MI:SS AM') NEW_DATE FROM dual;

Correct answer

Answer is correct, you can check what is difference:

SELECT 1, TO_CHAR(TO_DATE('19-Mar-2001', 'DD-Mon-YYYY'), 'fmDdspth "of" Month YYYY fmHH:MI:SS AM') NEW_DATE FROM dual
union
SELECT 2, TO_CHAR(TO_DATE('19-Mar-2001', 'DD-Mon-YYYY'), 'Ddspth "of" Month YYYY fmHH:MI:SS AM') NEW_DATE FROM dual
union
SELECT 3, TO_CHAR(TO_DATE('19-Mar-2001', 'DD-Mon-YYYY'), 'fmDdspth "of" Month YYYY HH:MI:SS AM') NEW_DATE FROM dual;

Last - wrong syntax

SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_DATE('19-Mar-2001', 'DD-Mon-YYYY'), 'fmDdspth "of" Month YYYY HH:HI:SS AM') NEW_DATE FROM dual;

questions.question_text: Which SQL statement displays the date March 19, 2001 in a format that appears as "Nineteenth of March 2001 12:00:00 AM"?

choices.D: SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_DATE(’19-Mar-2001’, ‘DD-Mon-YYYY), ‘fmDdspth "of" Month YYYYfmtHH:HI:SS AM') NEW_DATE FROM dual;
choices.B: SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_DATE(19-Mar-2001, DD-Mon-YYYY), Ddspth "of" Month YYYY fmHH:MI:SS AM’) NEW_DATE FROM dual;
choices.C: SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_DATE(’19-Mar-2001’, ‘DD-Mon-YYYY’), ‘fmDdspth "of" Month YYYY HH:MI:SS AM) NEW_DATE FROM dual;
choices.A: SELECT TO_CHAR(TO_DATE('19-Mar-2001, DD-Mon-YYYY), fmDdspth "of" Month YYYY fmHH:MI:SS AM’) NEW_DATE . FROM dual;

questions.question_text: Which SQL statements would display the value 1890.55 as $1, 890.55? (Choose three.)
